body:
My reasoning on dynamic libraries was related to user packages rather than
what we will provide in the mobile repo. But the users can always depend on
the NDK toolchain and System.loadLibrary if they have additional external
dependencies and they are only targeting Android -- it should be case if
you're loading a dynamic lib.

So, fine. We should move on, I'll dlsym. If we don't like it, we can
rethink and reimplement.

On Thu, Feb 26, 2015 at 7:19 AM, David Crawshaw <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> My current reasoning on dynamic libraries:
>
>    1. Every API we build in the mobile repository is for both Android and
>    iOS.
>    2. We cannot load dynamic libraries on iOS.
>    3. We can statically link on Android, except where licenses prohibit
>    it. License prohibitions on Android apply to iOS too.
>    4. We strongly prefer working in Go and minimizing C. (If everything
>    we needed from Android and iOS was available as a syscall, I would make
>    this work with CGO_ENABLED=0.)
>
> So for us to need a dynamic library: it must be necessary for implementing
> an API on Android that is available on iOS some other way, and licensing
> must prohibit static linking. I'm amazed we found even one example.
>
> It may be expedient to implement your audio package directly on OpenSL and
> you can if you like, but I think it would be of great value to game
> developers to have the full OpenAL available. So it would be nice to solve
> this, even if it means writing a script to generate a bunch of dlsym-based
> function bindings.
